title: Early data that arrives after the handshake completes
body: The conclusion there was that early data is relatively "safe" (for some definition of the term, see the draft for details) if the handshake completed.  Early data in a transport that provides ordered delivery will always arrive before the handshake completes.  But this is not the case in QUIC, or anything like DTLS.  We should offer some advice for these situations.

title: I'm sure that this was just Ben playing a prank
body: Added in #40.

title: Don't repeat TLS advice
body:
TLS mandates the use of anti-replay, but we were implying that it didn't, so
that text needed rewording.

I've moved this to the top of the list, since it is the first line of defense.
I've reworded to emphasize that it is mandatory, but then mention that it is
imperfect.

Closes #39.

title: Fix a few nits
body: found while reviewing the diff from the -00 to the -01

title: track mandatory server anti-replay measures
body: It looks like the TLS 1.3 spec is moving towards a strong requirement for servers to implement anti-replay measures with a strict bound on allowed numbers of replays; if this persists, then we do not need this document to further encourage servers to implement such measures, and can instead just state that they are required to have such measures.

title: Acknowledge some people
body: Closes #26.

title: Pick a status code
body: It looks like we're headed toward picking 425, but that can wait.

title: Add denial of service considerations
body:
This doesn't say not to use 503.  I think that we established that it's OK.

Instead this points out that overload isn't really helped by accepting early data.

(Like #27, this removes the TLS implementation requirements.  I'll have to manage a conflict somehow.)

title: Add TLS implementation requirements
body: More stuff cut out of #27.

title: There are some things that are safe to do
body: Moved from #27.

title: Servers can't delay if Early-Data is present
body: Moved from #27.

title: Intermediaries can retry
body:
We were already somewhat inconsistent with this, we already said

> Clients (user-agents and intermediaries) that sent the request in early data
MUST automatically retry the request [...]

This removes the conflict.

Closes #29

title: Awareness matters
body:
I didn't add the point about number.  If the mitigations mandated by TLS are
applied, the number of replays are bounded.

title: Let the intermediary retry
body: Several people have pointed out this as a possible performance enhancement.  I can't find a hole, assuming that the 4NN is reliably implemented by servers.

title: Add short overview section describing the basic model
body: We lost this at some point, probably in #3.  I think that this is important to have up front.

title: Save the 'be consistent' text
body: This rescues the good text from #25, on which we are converging on consensus to reject.

title: Acknowledge some people
body: Certainly Subodh, maybe also some others.

title: Make the client use Early-Data
body: Based on mailing list discussion.  This makes `Early-Data` mandatory any time that there is a chance that the request is processed before the handshake completes.  That's the most conservative approach - and I think we need to be conservative here, at least for now.

title: Improve security considerations
body: Just a small tweak.  We don't want to de-emphasize the impact of side-effects, which the original text did.

title: Allow the intermediary to generate 4NN (Too Early)
body: @ghedo asks that we explicitly allow this.  This is reasonable.

title: Just another reminder that you don't have to enable 0-RTT
body: Closes #21

title: If the gateway isn't sure that the origin supports Early-Data
body: ...then maybe it should disable 0-RTT.  We can recommend that in the last paragraph of the security considerations.

title: Add text on 0.5 RTT
body:
A server can use its first flight to send data.  

It's almost certainly safe to send the h2 connection preface here.  We can say that.

We should point to the text in TLS 1.3 that says that the 0.5 flight can't be used if client liveness or authentication is required.  I don't think that we need anything else.

title: On requests that are only partially in 0-RTT
body:
Fundamentally, these don't need special treatment, but we should say
that.

Closes #16.

title: On side effects
body:
The observation here is that side-effects aren't necessarily restricted
to the state of the resource, but also the server itself.  And it's not
the existence of the request that matters, but the actions that it
triggers.

title: The effect of generic anti-replay
body:
... is that replays are reduced from effectively unbounded, to a fixed
value.  This is a key point in the discussion of replays in TLS and
worth repeating here.

For @kaduk

title: Talk about requests that span 0-RTT and 1-RTT
body:
As a single stream, requests can start in early data and finish after the handshake completes.  This isn't necessarily a problem, but we should explain what the thinking is.

The model we've adopted here is that once the handshake is complete, whether the first part of the request was in early data doesn't matter.  This is on the basis that early data is retroactively blessed once the handshake completes.  What matters most is when the actions are triggered.  If a request is processed before the handshake completes, even partially, then the question of replay becomes relevant.

Needs some text.

title: two minor adjustments (0-RTT and "might have been")
body: Found while reading the latest version.

title: Tweaks
body: Collision sensors on high alert.

title: Stuff II
body: Mostly editorial, I think, but please review.

title: Shall we ship this thing?
body: Let's all give this a read over and see if it remains sane, but I think we're good enough for a -00.  Agree?

title: A more thorough explanation of the replay attack enabled by retrying
body: Closes #4, I hope.

title: mostly editorial stuff
body: email address, broken sentence, one rule not to send 422 without early data, one rule not to unconditionally add early-data. The rest is left for discussion in the issues.

title: servers must not generate 422 without early data header field
body:
"A server SHOULD NOT generate the 422 (Too Early) status code unless the request includes an Early-Data header field with a value of 1"

I think we should be stricter here and say MUST NOT. I still can't find a case where a server could decide to emit this code without being absolutely certain the client would be able to retry. The biggest problem I'm seeing is that SHOULD NOT will be enough of a signal for some dirty server implementations to use it to force a generic retry (eg: flow control) and that will force clients to implement support for it, diverting the initial purpose. So better use MUST NOT.

title: risk of getting multiple early-data header fields
body: "An intermediary MUST NOT add this header field with a value of 0 or remove a header field if it has a value of 1" : I see the point in case a request is transported over several gateways, but then it conflates the client's initial intent and what the next hope received. For example, it might be complicated for a client to remove this header field at the last moment once the connection is being established and the server says it doesn't accept early data. So the client might leave some early-data header fields in its request buffer and send them over a perfectly safe connection. But at the same time we don't want to let second or third level gateways remove the header field. I think in fact we need 3 values for the header field, the one used by the client and the one passed to the server. We want more or less "Early-data: sent" set by the client, replaced with "Early-data: received" by the first gateway, or the header field being removed (or set to "none") if in the end the request was not received as early data. And only "sent" would be allowed to be replaced, with "received" being sticky. I can propose some text.

title: risks for the client
body:
"This gives a client explicit control over whether a given request is exposed to the risk of replay."

For me the first risk the client takes by sending a request as early data is to see it being rejected and having to retry it differently. It's important because it helps decide whether or not idempotent requests should be sent this way or not, regardless of the replay risk.

In fact I *think* that if we place the replay avoidance paragraph before "reducing the risk", we may more easily enumerate the double risk the client has to accept to take (request being replayed, request getting rejected by the server).

title: Unclear explanation
body: I'm having a problem with this sentence : "This results in a potential replay where the early data is sent to one server instance and the connection attempt is separately allowed to complete where the server instance rejects the early data", I don't understand what situation it describes. The issue seems to be related to "separately allowed to complete".

title: So, I kind of ended up rewriting it...
Scope
body: It'd be nice if we could find a way to couch this as applying to not only TLS, but also QUIC and TFO.

title: Too Soon?
body: @mnot, WDYT?
